topics.title: Optional Practical Training (OPT)
topics.summary: OPT allows F-1 students to engage in temporary employment directly related to their major area of study, available before or after program completion.
eligibility: F-1 students who have been lawfully enrolled full-time for at least one academic year
Employment must be directly related to the student's major field of study
Student must be in valid F-1 status at the time of application
process_steps: Request OPT recommendation from Designated School Official (DSO)
DSO endorses Form I-20 and updates SEVIS record with OPT recommendation
File Form I-765, Application for Employment Authorization, with USCIS within 30 days of DSO recommendation
Include required fee, supporting documents, and copy of endorsed Form I-20
Await approval and receive Employment Authorization Document (EAD) before commencing employment
Report employment information to DSO and update SEVIS records as required
key_rules: Pre-completion OPT: Part-time (up to 20 hours per week) during academic sessions; full-time during breaks
Post-completion OPT: Full-time employment permitted after program completion
Maximum of 12 months of OPT per educational level (bachelor's, master's, doctorate)
Unemployment limit: 90 days total during the 12-month post-completion OPT period
Employment must be directly related to the student's major field of study
Cannot begin employment until EAD is received and valid
Must apply for post-completion OPT no later than 60 days after program completion date

timelines.earliest: 90 days before program completion date for post-completion OPT
timelines.latest: 60 days after program completion date for post-completion OPT

common_mistakes: Applying for OPT more than 30 days after DSO recommendation in SEVIS
Engaging in employment before receiving the EAD
Exceeding the 90-day unemployment limit during post-completion OPT
Engaging in employment not directly related to the major field of study
Failing to report employment changes to DSO within required timeframes
Not maintaining valid F-1 status during OPT period
consequences_of_violation: Possible removal from the United States

topics.title: Curricular Practical Training (CPT)
topics.summary: CPT allows F-1 students to engage in off-campus employment that is an integral part of the established curriculum, such as internships or cooperative education programs.
eligibility: F-1 students who have been lawfully enrolled full-time for at least one academic year
Employment must be an integral part of the established curriculum
Employment must be directly related to the student's major field of study
Student must be in valid F-1 status
process_steps: Obtain a job offer related to the major field of study
Request CPT authorization from DSO with job offer details
DSO verifies employment is integral to curriculum and updates SEVIS
DSO issues new Form I-20 with CPT authorization on page 2
Begin employment on or after the CPT start date listed on Form I-20
Report any changes in employment to DSO immediately
key_rules: Part-time CPT: Up to 20 hours per week during academic sessions
Full-time CPT: More than 20 hours per week, typically during breaks or if required by program
12 months or more of full-time CPT eliminates eligibility for post-completion OPT
Part-time CPT does not affect OPT eligibility
CPT authorization is employer-specific and date-specific
Cannot work before the CPT start date or after the end date on Form I-20
Must maintain full-time enrollment while on part-time CPT during academic sessions
No separate application to USCIS required - DSO authorization is sufficient

timelines.earliest: After completing one full academic year (9 months) of full-time enrollment
timelines.latest: Before the program end date listed on Form I-20

common_mistakes: Engaging in CPT employment without prior DSO authorization
Working before the CPT start date or after the end date
Exceeding authorized work hours during academic sessions
Accumulating 12 months or more of full-time CPT, which eliminates OPT eligibility
Failing to report employment changes or termination to DSO
Working for a different employer than authorized on Form I-20
consequences_of_violation: Possible removal from the United States

topics.title: STEM OPT Extension (24-month)
topics.summary: F-1 students who have earned degrees in designated STEM fields may apply for a 24-month extension of post-completion OPT, allowing up to 36 months total of practical training.
eligibility: F-1 students who have completed a degree in a STEM field listed on the STEM Designated Degree Program List
Currently in a valid period of post-completion OPT
Employment with an employer enrolled in E-Verify
Employment must be directly related to the STEM degree
Previous STEM degree must be from an accredited, SEVP-certified school
process_steps: Obtain job offer from E-Verify-enrolled employer
Complete Form I-983, Training Plan for STEM OPT Students, with employer
Request STEM OPT recommendation from DSO
DSO reviews Form I-983 and endorses Form I-20 with STEM OPT recommendation
DSO updates SEVIS record
File Form I-765 with USCIS before current OPT expires, including Form I-983
USCIS must receive application before current OPT expiration date
Await approval and receive new EAD
Report employment changes to DSO within 10 days
Submit self-evaluations via Form I-983 at 12 months and 24 months to DSO
key_rules: Must apply before current post-completion OPT expires
Employment must be directly related to the STEM degree
Employer must be enrolled in E-Verify and provide E-Verify company ID number
Must work at least 20 hours per week for the E-Verify employer
Self-employment is not permitted during STEM OPT
Unemployment limit: 150 days total (90 days from initial OPT plus 60 additional days during STEM OPT)
Must report changes in employment, address, or personal information to DSO within 10 days
Must submit self-evaluations at 12 and 24 months using Form I-983
DSO must validate student's SEVIS record every 6 months

timelines.earliest: 90 days before current OPT expiration date
timelines.latest: USCIS must receive application before current OPT expiration date

common_mistakes: Failing to submit Form I-983 with the application
Applying after current OPT has expired
Working for a non-E-Verify employer
Not reporting employment changes to DSO within 10 days
Missing self-evaluation deadlines at 12 and 24 months
Exceeding the 150-day total unemployment limit
Engaging in self-employment
Working less than 20 hours per week
consequences_of_violation: Possible removal from the United States
audience: Current F-1 students with STEM degrees on post-completion OPT

topics.title: Maintaining F-1 Status
topics.summary: F-1 students must comply with specific requirements throughout their program to maintain lawful nonimmigrant student status in the United States.
eligibility: All F-1 students admitted to the United States
Enrollment in a SEVP-certified school
Valid Form I-20 and passport
process_steps: Enroll full-time each academic term (minimum credit hours as defined by school)
Attend all classes and maintain satisfactory academic progress
Keep Form I-20 valid and request new I-20 for any program changes
Maintain valid passport at all times
Report address changes to DSO within 10 days
Obtain DSO authorization before dropping below full-time enrollment
Obtain proper authorization before engaging in any employment
Request program extension before program end date if needed
Depart United States within 60 days of program completion unless authorized for OPT or continuing studies
key_rules: Must maintain full-time enrollment each academic term (exceptions require DSO approval)
Cannot engage in unauthorized employment
On-campus employment limited to 20 hours per week during academic sessions
Must report address changes to DSO within 10 days of moving
Must report changes in program, major, or personal information to DSO
Cannot exceed 5 months of online/distance learning courses per academic year
Must attend the school listed on Form I-20
Must depart United States within 60 days after program completion unless continuing studies or on OPT
Must maintain valid passport (renew at least 6 months before expiration)
Cannot work off-campus without proper authorization (CPT, OPT, or economic hardship)

timelines.earliest: Upon initial entry to United States in F-1 status
timelines.latest: Throughout duration of F-1 program until completion or status change

common_mistakes: Dropping below full-time enrollment without DSO authorization
Engaging in unauthorized employment
Failing to report address changes within 10 days
Exceeding allowed work hours during academic sessions
Not maintaining valid passport
Failing to request program extension before program end date
Not reporting changes in program or personal information to DSO
Remaining in United States more than 60 days after program completion without authorization
consequences_of_violation: Ineligibility for benefits (OPT, CPT, program extension)
Possible removal from the United States
Bar from re-entry for 3 or 10 years depending on unlawful presence
Ineligibility for future nonimmigrant or immigrant visas

topics.title: Employment Authorization for F-1 Students
topics.summary: F-1 students may engage in employment only with proper authorization. Types include on-campus employment, CPT, OPT, and off-campus employment due to severe economic hardship.
eligibility: F-1 students maintaining valid status
On-campus: Available immediately upon enrollment
CPT/OPT: After completing one full academic year
Economic hardship: Must demonstrate severe economic hardship due to unforeseen circumstances
process_steps: Determine type of employment authorization needed
For on-campus: Obtain DSO authorization and job offer
For CPT: Request CPT authorization from DSO with job offer
For OPT: Request OPT recommendation from DSO, then file Form I-765 with USCIS
For economic hardship: File Form I-765 with USCIS, including evidence of severe economic hardship
Wait for authorization before beginning employment
Report employment information to DSO as required
key_rules: On-campus employment: Up to 20 hours per week during academic sessions; full-time during breaks. No USCIS application required - DSO authorization sufficient
CPT employment: Must be authorized by DSO on Form I-20 before employment begins. Must be integral to curriculum and related to major field of study
OPT employment: Requires EAD from USCIS before employment begins. Must be related to major field of study. 90-day unemployment limit for post-completion OPT

Economic hardship employment: Requires Form I-765 approval from USCIS. Must demonstrate severe economic hardship due to unforeseen circumstances beyond student's control. Limited to 20 hours per week during academic sessions
Unauthorized employment is a violation of F-1 status and results in loss of status
All off-campus employment (except on-campus) requires prior authorization
Employment authorization is specific to the type granted and cannot be interchanged
Must maintain valid F-1 status to retain employment authorization

timelines.earliest: On-campus: Upon enrollment. CPT/OPT: After one full academic year. Economic hardship: After one full academic year and demonstration of hardship

common_mistakes: Beginning employment before receiving proper authorization
Exceeding 20 hours per week during academic sessions for on-campus employment
Working off-campus without authorization
Using one type of employment authorization for a different type of employment
Failing to report employment changes to DSO
Continuing employment after authorization expires
Not maintaining valid F-1 status while on employment authorization
consequences_of_violation: Possible removal from the United States

topics.title: Social Security Number (SSN) for F-1 Students
topics.summary: F-1 students with authorized employment may apply for a Social Security Number, which is required for employment and tax reporting purposes in the United States.
eligibility: F-1 students with authorized employment (on-campus, CPT, or OPT)
Must have a job offer or current employment
Must have valid F-1 status and Form I-20
process_steps: Obtain employment authorization (on-campus job offer, CPT authorization on I-20, or EAD for OPT)
Wait at least 10 days after entry to United States or after DSO updates SEVIS (for SSA system verification)
Request SSN support letter from DSO (some schools provide this automatically)
Complete Form SS-5, Application for a Social Security Card
Gather required documents: valid passport, Form I-20, Form I-94 (print from CBP website), employment authorization document (EAD for OPT, or employment letter for on-campus/CPT)
Visit local Social Security Administration office with all documents
Submit application and wait for SSN card to arrive by mail (typically 2-4 weeks)
key_rules: SSN is issued only for employment purposes - not required for non-employment activities like opening bank accounts
Must have authorized employment before applying
Must wait at least 10 days after entry or SEVIS update for SSA to verify status in system
SSN is permanent and does not expire
Cannot begin employment without SSN if employer requires it for payroll
Must present original documents (not copies) at SSA office
SSN is required for tax reporting and filing tax returns
Unauthorized employment does not qualify for SSN

timelines.earliest: 10 days after entry to United States or after DSO updates SEVIS record, and after receiving employment authorization
timelines.latest: As soon as possible after obtaining employment authorization to avoid payroll delays

common_mistakes: Applying for SSN without employment authorization or job offer
Applying too soon after entry (before 10-day waiting period)
Not bringing all required original documents to SSA office
Applying without valid F-1 status
Thinking SSN is required for non-employment purposes like bank accounts
Not waiting for SSA system to update after SEVIS changes
consequences_of_violation: Delay or denial of SSN issuance
Inability to receive wages from employer
Issues with tax reporting and filing
Potential problems with employment eligibility verification
Need to reapply with correct documentation
audience: Current F-1 students with authorized employment
